header.title: Tarot Courtyard Course Lesson Two of five: Water

central_thesis: This lesson aims to deepen the understanding and practice of tarot by exploring the fundamental role of intuition and feelings, connecting them to the elemental energy of Water, and introducing a practical framework for interpreting Court Cards as both personality types and energetic manifestations within a reading.

structure_content.chapter_title: A Welcome from the Fool's Guild
structure_content.summary: Introduces the second lesson, focusing on intuition and feelings, encouraging a diverse approach to tarot study, and providing a forum for questions and discussion, emphasizing continuous review and updates to course content.

structure_content.chapter_title: The Second Week Begins at the Well
structure_content.summary: Examines the ongoing debate between intuitive and structured approaches to tarot reading, asserting that tarot reflects all aspects of life. It challenges the student to identify real-life situations within the tarot deck to demonstrate its comprehensive nature.

Explores intuition as a 'rapid knowing without reason' often experienced physically. It introduces 'The Cards Go Walking,' a physical exercise to develop intuitive recognition of card relationships without conscious thought, and notes the Golden Dawn's association of intuition with 'The Lovers' card.

Presents methods for developing an emotional and sensory connection to individual cards, using the Five of Swords as an example. It includes a practical exercise for sorting an entire deck based on immediate emotional responses into 'POSITIVE,' 'NEGATIVE,' 'NEUTRAL,' and 'NOT SURE' piles.

Connects tarot to psychological personality typing, specifically Myers-Brigg/Jungian categories. It maps these types to the four tarot suits (Swords-Thinking, Cups-Feeling, Pentacles-Sensing, Wands-Intuition) and introduces the application of Court Cards to represent different personality traits or people.

Provides a structured overview of the sixteen Court Cards, aligning them with the four elements and four 'levels of operation' (Page, Knight, Queen, King) representing different energetic phases. It clarifies that Court Cards are 'stereotypes' and offers three primary interpretation methods: as real people, parts of the querent's personality, or manifesting energies.

Concludes the lesson by symbolizing the mastery of the element of Water through the Ace of Cups, representing deeper understanding, love of learning, and a mystical unity with the subject matter. It highlights Aces as 'seeds of the elements.'

key_concepts.definition: Described as 'rapid knowing without reason,' often felt physically, and sometimes perceived as independent of prior knowledge. The Golden Dawn tradition viewed 'The Lovers' card as picturing intuition.

The four tarot suits correspond to elements: Swords with Air (Thoughts, Learning), Wands with Fire (Ambition, Spiritual Path), Cups with Water (Emotions, Love, Relationships), and Pentacles with Earth (Material, Wealth, Health).

Comprising 16 cards, they are presented as 'stereotypes' (not archetypes) representing specific energies and personality types. They can be interpreted as real people, aspects of the querent's personality, or a necessary energy manifesting in a situation.

A psychological framework used to categorize personality into four types (Thinking, Feeling, Sensing, Intuition), which are mapped to the four tarot suits to provide a psychological lens for understanding elemental energies and Court Cards.
The core focus of this lesson, associated with Cups, emotions, feelings, love, and relationships. It is the elemental basis for developing intuitive understanding in tarot reading.

Represented as 'the seeds of the elements,' signifying beginnings, deeper understanding, and potential rather than the elements themselves. The Ace of Cups specifically denotes a seed of deeper emotional and intuitive comprehension.

practical_system.description: The practical system outlined in this lesson focuses on cultivating intuition and emotional resonance with tarot cards. It combines sensory awareness exercises, reflective inquiry, and categorization techniques to build a personal and intuitive understanding of the deck's symbolism and energetic dynamics. The approach is experiential, encouraging the practitioner to 'feel' the cards and observe internal and external responses rather than relying solely on intellectual interpretation.
tools: Pen and paper for listing and note-taking
Access to an online forum for discussion and supervisor interaction
rituals: Finding Life Events in Tarot: Create a list of seven personal or observed life events (from daily activities, social interactions, or media) and then search the tarot deck to find cards that depict or correspond to these events, noting the clarity and nature of the correspondence.

The Cards Go Walking: Draw three random tarot cards and place them side-by-side. Place a finger on the left-hand and right-hand cards, fixing gaze on the center. Allow the fingers to intuitively reposition the outer cards, observing any movement (e.g., sudden, vibrating, orbiting) without conscious interpretation, to develop a sensory intuition for card relationships.

Emotional Card Sorting: Go through the entire tarot deck quickly and instinctively, placing each card into one of four categories based on immediate emotional response: POSITIVE FEELINGS, NEGATIVE FEELINGS, NEUTRAL, or NOT SURE. Subsequently, revisit the 'NOT SURE' pile to assign cards to one of the other three categories if possible.

Sensory Exploration of a Card: Select a card (e.g., Five of Swords) and first identify immediate emotional responses (friendly, antagonistic, positive, negative, neutral, alien). Then, engage other senses by imagining accompanying sounds or music that fit the card's atmosphere, tone, and theme to deepen emotional appreciation.

Connecting Court Cards to People: Apply the elemental and rank correspondences of the Court Cards to individuals in one's life (family, friends) to understand their personality traits through the lens of tarot archetypes (e.g., 'Queen of Pentacles' for a 'Sensing' mother).

relevant_quotes.text: This second lesson looks at reading tarot as a general skill, and considers how we learn tarot and practice the art. We give exercises for developing intuition and deepen our appreciation of a card to see what our feelings teach us.
Today, the topic of chat is on the role that intuition plays in tarot. Some people are opining that intuition is essential... whereas others are arguing for a more structured approach...
We should consider that even the debates about how to approach tarot cards is pictured within the cards themselves – all life is truly here, and art is our mirror!
Intuition can be thought of as a “rapid knowing without reason” and sometimes it is seen as being independent of all “previous knowledge and experience”.
It's important as a tarot reader to find the location or sensory representation of 'intuition' for yourself. Then you can work towards it whilst reading – a sort of internal “hot or cold” system!
The role and relationship of intuition and knowledge in tarot is obviously one of preference.
difficulty comes in knowing which to interpret – always go for (3) as it can then be seen to manifest as either (1) or (2).

critical_analysis.relevance: This lesson offers a fundamental and accessible entry point into intuitive tarot reading, bridging academic discussion with practical application. It is highly relevant for establishing a personal, felt connection to the cards beyond rote memorization, which is crucial for developing fluid and insightful readings. By contextualizing intuition within a broader debate about reading styles and linking it to established psychological frameworks (Jungian types, Myers-Brigg), the text provides a robust theoretical foundation while simultaneously offering concrete, experiential exercises. Its emphasis on Water and feelings is central to many esoteric traditions, making it a foundational piece for understanding emotional and psychic currents in divination.
critical_analysis.target_audience: The target audience includes both tarot beginners seeking a structured yet intuitive approach and experienced practitioners looking to deepen their intuitive skills. It caters to those interested in the psychological and philosophical underpinnings of tarot, as well as individuals who prefer hands-on, experiential learning. The course is designed for self-study but encourages forum participation, appealing to those who value community learning alongside personal development.
